title: How to Remove Garlic Smell from Your Hands

steps.headline: Rub your hands with stainless steel to get rid of the odor.
steps.description: This is a highly recommended old wives' tale! Turn on the tap with cold, running water and get a stainless steel spoon or a different stainless steel utensil. Then use the spoon to rub your fingers and palms vigorously under the cold water. Do this for 1-2 minutes before checking to see if the smell has started to disappear. If the garlic odor remains, spend another few minutes working the stainless steel in your hands. You don't have to just use a spoon, as anything made out of stainless steel will have the same effect. You can also try a sink, a faucet, or a specialty stainless steel bar of "soap."

steps.headline: Squeeze lemon on to your hands for a pleasant, citrus scent.
steps.description: Sometimes the best way to get rid of a strong garlic smell is to simply hide it with something that smells nicer! Slice a lemon in half and squeeze the juice generously into your palms. Then use your fingers to rub the juice over your hands fully, taking care to get the juice under your nails and in between your fingers. Although lemon can give your hands a lovely scent, it's best to use this method with caution. Check your hands for any cuts or dry skin before you add the lemon, as otherwise, it can irritate your skin and sting.

steps.headline: Use coffee beans to hide the smell and to exfoliate your skin.
steps.description: If you're a coffee-lover, then this will be welcome news! Get 3-4 coffee beans or a small spoonful of ground beans and place these into your palm. Rub your hands together gently and massage the coffee into your skin, paying special attention to between your fingers and under your nails. Then enjoy the pleasant smell and your soft, exfoliated skin. If you use coffee grounds, you'll need to rinse your hands afterward.

steps.headline: Rub toothpaste into your hands for a refreshing, minty scent.
steps.description: As long as you don't mind your hands smelling like toothpaste, then this is a very effective solution! Take a tube of regular mint or spearmint toothpaste and place a dollop onto each hand. Rub your hands together to spread the toothpaste over your palms, fingers, and the backs of your hands. Then rinse your hands thoroughly with soapy water to wash away the toothpaste.

steps.headline: Make a baking soda and salt paste to neutralize the garlic smell.
steps.description: Baking soda and salt are wonderful for getting rid of many different unpleasant odors, including garlic! Place 1 tsp (5 g) of salt and 2 tsp (10 g) of baking soda into a small bowl. Then add 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of water and stir the mixture until it forms a thick paste. Rub the paste into your hands and then rinse it away with water to get rid of the smell. Don't use this method if your skin is dry or sore, as it might sting.

steps.headline: Spray perfume or cologne on your hands to quickly mask the smell.
steps.description: Although it may not always be practical to use perfume to get rid of the garlic smell, it can be effective if you need a quick fix. Spritz the back of 1 hand with the perfume or cologne and then rub this onto the back of your other hand. Then rub your hands together to spread the fragrance over your palms and fingers. Avoid spritzing your hands with perfume or cologne if you're going to be touching other food products.

steps.headline: Shake the garlic bulb in a jar to peel it without touching it.
steps.description: This is an easy way to separate the garlic cloves and to remove the skin without needing to handle the garlic! Simply get a glass jar with a lid and place the garlic bulb inside the jar. Screw on the lid tightly and shake the jar for 2-3 minutes. When you can see that all of the cloves are peeled, pour the contents of the jar into a bowl and use a fork to remove the individual cloves that you need. At first, the garlic bulb will begin to separate into cloves. If you continue to shake the jar, the garlic skin will then start to peel away.

steps.headline: Crush or mine the garlic with a garlic press to avoid touching it.
steps.description: Although there will be some instances where you need to touch garlic, avoiding it as much as possible will help to keep the pesky smell away. Instead of crushing or mincing garlic using your hands and a knife, try using a garlic press instead. You can purchase garlic presses from home department stores and some grocery stores. Alternatively, use a food processor to mince the garlic.

steps.headline: Wear gloves to avoid touching the garlic with your bare skin.
steps.description: Although gloves can seem like a nuisance, they are effective at keeping your hands odor-free! Choose thin latex or nitrile gloves so that you can still easily work with your hands. You can find disposable, food-grade gloves at supermarkets, department stores, or bulk food stores. Gloves are also effective for preventing smells like onion and ginger remaining on your hands too. Avoid using thick gloves, as these can make handling the garlic or using utensils very difficult.
